data.message: First released? It hasn't even been released.

It has always been the same price Adam. 
Also you are right, you shouldn't pay $1600 (and change if you include taxes btw) to test the product. You should pay that premium if you intend to do something that will give you a return on that investment. 2cents.
Gary Doan He's referring to prototype to be tested.
The explorer program was made specifically for app developers, people who, if successful, stand to make back that investment and more.

good story, Adam.  i'm a lowly bank clerk, and was recently offered by the bank to "volunteer" to test out its mobile products using our personal smart phones (android or iOS only).  however, the bank only gave me a blackberry for business use, yet wants its employees to test products using people's personal smart phones for free.  I'm was thinking:  why would i want to do this for free using my own phone, and my own time?

the problem is you don't get the same type of attention and excitement when you offer someone something for free. Money puts up a wall, creates attraction, anticipation, want... It's the reason people statistically engage more often within apps they've paid money for. 

That being said, the $1500 is a tough pill to swallow. Google is historically terrible at launching products. Wave, G+, Google Glass... all great things released in self defeating ways.

I think the high price is to get the product to the right people who would actually use it and appreciate what it can do. If we lowered the price to $200.00 everybody would try to get a pair only to stick it in a drawer and not give back any useful feedback to help improve the product.
Steve Clingan there are other ways to ensure that google glass falls into the right hands than charging 1.6k.
